itemDescription: English First World War observer/gunner flying ace

wikipedia_page.main: Lieutenant Arthur William Hammond was an English World War I flying ace credited with five aerial victories as an observer/gunner.

response: Although its principal role was not air-to-air combat, it still had one flying ace among its ranks in Arthur William Hammond. It also numbered the first aviation Victoria Cross winners in its ranks, in Second Lieutenant Rhodes-Moorhouse and Lieutenant Alan Arnett McLeod.
* Arthur William Hammond (1890–1959), British World War I flying ace

* Eighteen-year-old Canadian fighter pilot Alan Arnett McLeod of the Royal Flying Corps No. 2 Squadron, and his observer Arthur William Hammond, shot down four German Fokker fighter planes over Albert, Somme, France before their Armstrong Whitworth plane was shot down. McLeod managed to crash-land in no man's land where, despite being seriously injured himself, carried the badly wounded Hammond to the British lines. McLeod received the Victoria Cross for his actions on September 4 at the age of 19, becoming the youngest airman to be awarded the medal in World War I.Kilduff, Peter, The Red Baron: Beyond the Legend, London: Cassell, 1994, , pp. 16-17
